article.paragraph: Cheddaris a largevillageandcivil parishes in Englandcivil parishin theSedgemoordistrict of the English county ofSomerset. It is situated on the southern edge of theMendip Hills,convert9mikm0north-west ofWells, SomersetWells. The civil parish includes theHamlet (place)hamletsof Nyland and Bradley Cross. The village, which has its own parish council, has a population of 5,755 and the parish has an acreage ofconvert8592acresas of 1961.cite webCheddar CP/AP through time acreagehttp://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/data_cube_page.jsp?data_themeA vision of Britain through time12 February 2011

Cheddar Gorge, on the northern edge of the village, is the largestcanyongorgein theUnited Kingdomand includes severalshow cavesincludingGough's Cave. The gorge has been a centre of human settlement sinceNeolithictimes, including aAnglo-SaxonsSaxonpalace. It has a temperate climate and provides a unique geological and biological environment that has been recognised by the designation of severalSites of Special Scientific Interest.cite webCheddar Gorge and Caveshttp://www.bristol-link.co.uk/entertainment/cheddar-gorge.htmBristol-link31 January 2011It is also the site of severallimestonequarryquarries. The village gave its name toCheddar cheeseand has been a centre forGarden strawberrystrawberrygrowing. The crop was formerly transported on theCheddar Valley lineCheddar Valley rail line, which closed in the late 1960s but is now a cycle path. The village is now a major tourist destination with several cultural and community facilities, including the Cheddar Show Caves Museum.cite webCheddar Man—Museum of Prehistoryhttp://www.cheddarcaves.co.uk/section.php?xSec31 January 2011Cheddar Caves

The village supports a variety of community groups including religious, sporting and cultural organisations. Several of these are based on the site ofThe Kings of Wessex Academy, which is the largest educational establishment.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: The name Cheddar comes from theOld Englishwordceodor, meaning deep dark cavity or pouch.Cite bookAtthillRobinMendip: A new study197675David & CharlesNewton Abbott0-7153-7297-1

There is evidence of occupation from theNeolithicperiod in Cheddar. Britain's oldest complete human skeleton,Cheddar Man, estimated to be 9,000 years old, was found in Cheddar Gorge in 1903.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/naturescalendar/summer/honeypots/cheddar/cheddar_gorge.shtmlTourist hotspots—Cheddar Gorge[[BBC]]12 August 2007Older remains from theUpper PaleolithicUpper Late Palaeolithicera (12,00013,000 years ago) have been found.cite webhttp://webapp1.somerset.gov.uk/her/details.asp?prnGough's Cave, Cheddar Gorge, CheddarSomerset Historic Environment Record[[Somerset County Council]]January 19837 February 2011There is some evidence of aBronze Agefield system at theBatts Combe quarrysite. There is also evidence of Bronze Age barrows at the mound in theLongwood valley, which if man-made it is likely to be a field system.cite webhttp://www.ubss.org.uk/resources/proceedings/vol23/UBSS_Proc_23_1_9-16.pdf Results of geophysical surveys at two barrow sites in Cheddar and Priddy Parishes, Mendip Jodie Lewis 2003 Proc. Univ. Bristol Spelaeol. Soc. 2003 [[University of Bristol]] 11 11 July 2012 The remains of a Roman villa have been excavated in the grounds of the currentRectoryvicarage.

File:Saxon palace at Cheddar.jpgthumbReconstruction of the Saxon royal palace at Cheddar around 1000 ADThe village of Cheddar had been important during theRoman BritainRomanandSaxoneras. There was aCheddar Palaceroyal palace at Cheddarduring the Saxon period, which was used on three occasions in the 10th century to host theWitenagemot.cite webhttp://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/arch-769-1/ahds/dissemination/pdf/vol06-07/6_053_066.pdfPDFRahtzPhillipArchaeology Data ServiceThe Saxon and Medieval Palaces at Cheddar, Somerset-an Interim Report of Excavations in I 960-6231 March 2008The ruins of the palace were excavated in the 1960s.cite webhttp://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/hes/downloads/Somerset_EUS_Cheddar.pdfCheddar Archaeological AssessmentRichardsonMiranda2003Somerset Extensive Urban Survey[[Somerset County Council]]PDF26 May 2014They are located on the grounds ofThe Kings of Wessex Academy, together with a 14th century chapel dedicated toColumbanusSt. Columbanus.cite webhttp://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id[[Images of England]][[English Heritage]]Former chapel dedicated to St Columbanus31 March 2008Roman remains have also been uncovered at the site.Cite newsSchool dig uncovers Roman graveBBC Newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/somerset/4630806.stm20 January 200631 March 2008Cheddar was listed in theDomesday Bookof 1086 asCeder, meaning "Shear Water", from theOld EnglishscearandCeltic languagesCelticdwr.Cite bookRobinsonStephenSomerset Place Names1992The Dovecote Press Ltd43Wimborne, Dorset1-874336-03-2As early as 1130 AD, theCheddar Gorgewas recognised as one of the "Four wonders of England". Historically, Cheddar's source of wealth was farming and cheese making for which it was famous as early as 1170 AD.cite bookWest Country History: Somerset2002MurielSearleVenton Publications130http://books.google.com/?id978-1-84150-802-37 February 2011The parish was part of theWinterstokeHundred (county subdivision)Hundred.cite webSomerset Hundredshttp://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/SOM/Miscellaneous/GENUKI9 September 2011

The manor of Cheddar was deforested in 1337 andRalph of ShrewsburyBishop Ralphwas granted a licence by the King to create a hunting forest.cite bookBondJamesSomerset Parks and GardensSomerset Books251998978-0861834655

As early as 1527 there are records ofwatermillson the river.In the 17th and 18th centuries, there were several watermills which groundwheatcornand made paper, with 13 mills on theCheddar YeoYeoat the peak, declining to seven by 1791 and just three by 1915.cite webhttp://www.parish-council.com/Cheddar/index.asp?pageidCheddar Parish CouncilJohnOuthwaiteA Short History of Cheddar30 March 2010In theVictorian erait also became a centre for the production of clothing.cite webhttp://www.cheddarvillage.co.uk/about.htmA brief history of CheddarCheddar Web Site30 March 2010The last mill, used as a shirt factory, closed in the early 1950s.William Wilberforcesaw the poor conditions of the locals when he visited Cheddar in 1789. He inspiredHannah Morein her work to improve the conditions of theMendip HillsMendipminers and agricultural workers.Cite bookCoyshA.W.http://books.google.com/?idE.J.MasonV.WaiteThe Mendips197796Robert Hale LtdLondon0-7091-6426-2In 1801,convert4400acrekm2of common land were enclosed under theInclosure Acts.Cite bookHavindenMichaelThe Somerset Landscape1982Hodder and StoughtonLondonThe making of the English landscape1330-340-20116-9

Tourism of theCheddar GorgeCheddar gorge and cavesbegan with the opening of theCheddar Valley Railwayin 1869.cite webAbout Cheddar Village, Somersethttp://www.cheddarvillage.co.uk/about.htmCheddar Village12 February 2011

Cheddar, its surrounding villages and specifically the gorge has been subject to flooding. In theGreat Flood of 1968the flow of water washed large boulders down the gorge, washed away cars, and damaged the cafe and the entrance to Gough's Cave.cite news40 years since the Great Gorge Floodhttp://www.thewestonmercury.co.uk/news/40_years_since_the_great_gorge_flood_1_32177624 February 2011Western Mercury10 July 2008cite webThe Chew Valley floods of 1968http://www.publow-with-pensford-pc.gov.uk/pub/backlook/env_agency_leaflet.pdfEnvironment Agency24 February 2011
article.heading: Government
article.paragraph: Cheddar is recognised as a village.cite webhttp://www.cheddarparishcouncil.org/documents/CPC%20-%20Parish%20Plan.pdfPDFCheddar Parish PlanCheddar Parish Council30 March 2010cite webhttp://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/hes/downloads/EUS_CheddarText.pdfAn archaeological assessment of CheddarMirandaRichardsonPDFSomerset Extensive Urban SurveySomerset County Council12Cheddar is one of 30 of the 45 historic towns covered by this project which is not classed as a town in the County Structure Plan.4 March 20112003The adjacent settlement ofAxbridge, although only about a third the population of Cheddar, is a town.cite webhttp://www.infobritain.co.uk/Axbridge.htmAxbridge, and King John's Hunting Lodge, SomersetInfoBritain5 April 2010cite webhttp://www.axbridge-tc.gov.uk/visitor/history.htmlAxbridge: HistoryAxbridge Town CouncilAxbridge: Information for Visitors and Residents maintained by Axbridge Town Council4 March 2011cite webhttp://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/hes/downloads/EUS_AxbridgeText.pdfAn archaeological assessment of AxbridgeMirandaRichardsonPDFSomerset Extensive Urban SurveySomerset County Council4–54 March 20112001This apparently illogical situation is explained by the relative importance of the two places in historic times. While Axbridge grew in importance as a centre for cloth manufacturing in theTudor dynastyTudorperiod and gained a charter fromJohn of EnglandKing John, Cheddar remained a more dispersed mining and dairy-farming village. Its population grew with the arrival of the railways in theVictorian eraand the advent of tourism.cite webAxbridge Cheddar—Location Reporthttp://www.nsdatabase.co.uk/locationdetail.cfm?locationidNSDatabase7 February 2011

TheParish councils in Englandparish council, which has 15 members who are elected for four years,cite webhttp://www.parish-council.com/Cheddar/index.asp?pageidYour CouncilCheddar Parish Council30 March 2010is responsible for local issues, including setting an annual precept (local rate) to cover the council's operating costs and producing annual accounts for public scrutiny. The parish council evaluates local planning applications and works with the police, district council officers, andNeighbourhood Watch (UK)neighbourhood watchgroups on matters of crime, security, and traffic. The parish council's role also includes initiating projects for the maintenance and repair of parish facilities, as well as consulting with the district council on the maintenance, repair, and improvement of highways, drainage, footpaths, public transport, and street cleaning. Conservation matters (including trees and listed buildings) and environmental issues are also the responsibility of the council.cite webhttp://www.parish-council.com/cheddar/index.asp?pageidYour CouncilCheddar Parish Council4 March 2011

The village is in the 'Cheddar and Shipham'Wards and electoral divisions of the United Kingdomelectoral ward. After includingShiphamthe total population of the ward taken at theUnited Kingdom Census 20112011 censusis 6,842.cite webhttp://www.ukcensusdata.com/cheddar-and-shipham-e05008905#sthash.NORE1ey7.dpbsCheddar and Shipham ward 2011.Retrieved 6 March 2015

File:Cheddar fire station.jpgthumbCheddar Fire Station has a crew of retained firefightersThe village falls within thenon-metropolitan districtofSedgemoor, which was formed on 1 April 1974 under theLocal Government Act 1972. It was previously part ofAxbridge Rural District.cite webAxbridge RDhttp://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/unit/10025515A vision of Britain Through TimeUniversity of Portsmouth4 January 2014Sedgemoor is responsible forplanning permissionlocal planningandBuilding regulations in the United Kingdombuilding control, local roads,council housing,environmental health, markets and fairs, refuse collection and recycling, cemeteries and crematoria, leisure services, parks, and tourism.cite bookAxbridge, Rural District, Somerset. The official guide1965Axbridge, Rural District60http://books.google.com/?id7 February 20110-7174-0070-0Somerset County Councilis responsible for running the largest and most expensive local services such asLocal Education Authorityeducation,social services, the library, roads, public transport,trading standards, waste disposal and strategic planning, although fire, police and ambulance services are provided jointly with other authorities through theDevon and Somerset Fire and Rescue Service,Avon and Somerset Constabularyand theSouth Western Ambulance Service.cite webhttp://www.somersetstrategicpartnership.org.uk/about-the-ssp/Somerset Strategic PartnershipAbout the Somerset Strategic Partnership5 March 2011

It is also part of theWells (UK Parliament constituency)Wellscounty constituencyrepresented in theBritish House of CommonsHouse of Commonsof theParliament of the United Kingdom.Parliamentary Constituencies in the county of SomersetGovernment News. Retrieved 14 November 2001.It elects oneMember of ParliamentMember of Parliament (MP)by thefirst past the postsystem of election, and is part of theSouth West England (European Parliament constituency)South West England constituencyof theEuropean Parliamentwhich elects sixMembers of the European ParliamentMEPsusing thed'Hondt methodofparty-list proportional representation.

Cheddar isTwin towns and sister citiestwinnedwithFelsberg, HessenFelsberg, Germany andVernouillet, Eure-et-LoirVernouillet, France, and it has an active programme of exchange visits.cite webhttp://www.sedgemoorgermantwinning.org.uk/cheddar.htmlCheddar / Felsberg Vernouillet Friendship Association (CFVFA)Sedgemopor German Twinning Association30 March 2010Initially, Cheddar twinned with Felsberg in 1984. In 2000, Cheddar twinned with Vernouillet, which had also been twinned with Felsberg.cite newsCheddar Felsberg And Vernouillet Friendship Associationhttp://cheddaraxbridgepaper.co.uk/newspop.php?paperid25 December 2010Nailsea e-paperCheddar also has a friendship link withOcho RiosinSaint Ann Parish, Jamaica.cite newshttp://www.thisissomerset.co.uk/news/Credit-crunch-hits-trip-Jamaica/article-1022312-detail/article.htmlCheddar Valley Gazette26 May 2009Credit crunch hits trip from Jamaica25 December 2010
article.heading: Geography

article.paragraph: The area is underlain by Black Rock slate, Burrington Oolite and Clifton Down Limestone of theCarboniferousLimestoneSeries, which containOoliteoolithsandfossildebris on top ofOld Red Sandstone, and byDolomiteDolomitic Conglomerateof theKeuper. Evidence forVariscan orogenyis seen in the sheared rock and cleaved shales. In many places weathering of these strata has resulted in the formation of immature calcareous soils.cite webThe Cheddar ComplexEnglish Naturehttp://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003940.pdf17 July 2006PDF
article.heading: Gorge and caves
article.paragraph: MainCheddar GorgeCheddar Gorge, which is located on the edge of the village, is the largestcanyongorgein the United Kingdom.cite webhttp://www.agiweb.org/geotimes/may05/Travels0505.htmlCheddar Gorge: Not entirely cheesyMay 2005Geotimes, a publication of the American Geological Institute12 August 2007The gorge is the site of the Cheddar Caves, whereCheddar Manwas found in 1903.Older remains from theUpper PaleolithicUpper Late Palaeolithicera (12,00013,000 years ago) have been found.The caves, produced by the activity of an underground river, containstalactitesandstalagmites.Gough's Cave, which was discovered in 1903,cite webhttp://piclib.nhm.ac.uk/results.asp?imageGough's Cave excavation siteNatural History Museum7 February 2011leads aroundconvert400myd0oninto the rock-face, and contains a variety of large rock chambers and formations.Cox's Cave, discovered in 1837,cite webhttp://www.bgs.ac.uk/mendips/localities/cheddar.htmlCheddar Gorge4 March 2011British Geological Surveyis smaller but contains many intricate formations. A further cave houses a children's entertainment walk known as the "Crystal Quest".cite webhttp://www.cheddarcaves.co.uk/section.php/22/1/cox_s_cave___the_crystal_questCox's Cave and the Crystal CaveCheddar Caves and Gorge18 December 2009http://web.archive.org/web/20091129222749/http://www.cheddarcaves.co.uk/section.php/22/1/cox_s_cave___the_crystal_quest29 November 2009

Cheddar Gorge, including Cox's Cave, Gough's Cave and other attractions, has become a tourist destination, attracting about 500,000 visitors per year.cite webhttp://www.thebmc.co.uk/Feature.aspx?idAccess Q&A: Cheddar GorgeBritish Mountaineering Council199912 August 2007In a 2005 poll ofRadio Timesreaders, following its appearance on the 2005 television programmeSeven Natural Wonders, Cheddar Gorge was named as the second greatest natural wonder in Britain, surpassed only by theDan yr Ogofcaves.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/mid_/4735935.stmCaves win 'natural wonder' vote[[BBC]]2 August 20057 February 2011
article.heading: Sites of Special Scientific Interest
article.paragraph: File:Cheddarreser.JPGthumbrightCheddar Reservoirat dusk, looking towards the western edge of theMendip HillsandCrook Peak to Shute Shelve HillCrook PeakThere are several large and uniqueSites of Special Scientific Interest(SSSI) around the village.

Cheddar Reservoiris a near-circular artificial reservoir operated byBristol Water. Dating from the 1930s, it has a capacity of 135 million gallons (614,000 cubic metres).cite webhttp://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/cheddar-info.aspCheddar Reservoir IntroductionBristol Water30 March 2010The reservoir is supplied with water taken from theCheddar Yeo, which rises in Gough's Cave in Cheddar Gorge and is a tributary of theRiver Axe (Bristol Channel)River Axe. The inlet grate for theconvert54inm1onwater pipe that is used to transport the water can be seen next to thesensory gardenin Cheddar Gorge.cite webAxbridge Raw Water Treatment Workshttp://www.ceequal.co.uk/awards_035.htmAxbridge Raw WaterCEEQUAL5 March 2011It has been designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) due to its wintering waterfowl populations.cite webhttp://www.english-nature.org.uk/Special/sssi/sssi_details.cfm?sssi_idEnglish Nature SSSI information for Cheddar Reservoir[[English Nature]]7 February 2011

Cheddar Woodand the smaller Macall's Wood form abiological Site of Special Scientific Interestfrom what remains of the wood of theBishops of Bath and Wellsin the 13th century and ofEdmund I of EnglandKing Edmundthe Magnificent's wood in the 10th. During the 19th century, its lower fringes were grubbed out to makeGarden strawberrystrawberryfields. Most of these have been allowed to revert to woodland. The wood wascoppiceduntil 1917.Cite bookAspects of the medieval landscape of SomersetAstonMichaelMick Aston1988[[Somerset County Council]]0-86183-129-230This site compromises a wide range of habitats which include ancient and secondary semi-natural broadleaved woodland, unimproved neutral grassland, and a complex mosaic ofcalcareous grasslandand acidic dry dwarf-shrub heath. Cheddar Wood is one of only a few English stations forStarved Wood-sedge(Carex depauperata).Lithospermum purpurocaeruleumPurple Gromwell(Lithospermum purpurocaeruleum), a nationally rare plant, also grows in the wood.ButterfliesincludeSilver-washed Fritillary(Argynnis paphia),Dark Green Fritillary(Argynnis aglaja),Pearl-bordered Fritillary(Boloria euphrosyne),Holby Blue(Celastrina argiolus) andBrown Argus(Aricia agestis). Theslug(Arion fasciatus), which has a restricted distribution in the south of England, and theSoldier beetle(Cantharis fusca) also occur.cite webCheddar Wood[[English Nature]]http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003970.pdfPDF17 July 2006

By far the largest of the SSSIs is calledCheddar Complexand coversconvert441.3haacre1of the gorge, caves and the surrounding area. It is important because of both biological and geological features. It includes four SSSIs, formerly known as Cheddar Gorge SSSI, August Hole/Longwood Swallet SSSI, GB Cavern Charterhouse SSSI and Charterhouse on-Mendip SSSI.cite webThe Cheddar Complex[[English Nature]]http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003940.pdfPDF17 July 2006It is partly owned by theNational Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural BeautyNational Trustwho acquired it in 1910cite webNature and the National Trusthttp://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-chl/w-countryside_environment/w-nature/w-nature-strategy.htmNational Trust4 March 2011and partly managed by theSomerset Wildlife Trust.cite webCheddar Complexhttp://www.somersetwildlife.org/cheddar_complex.htmlSomerset Wildlife Trust4 March 2011
article.heading: Quarries
article.paragraph: File:Batts Combe Quarry from tower.JPGalt=Exposed stone face of quarry, and buildingsthumbBatts Combe Quarry from the lookout tower aboveCheddar GorgeClose to the village and gorge areBatts Combe quarryandCallow Rock quarry, two of the activeQuarries of the Mendip Hillswherelimestoneis still extracted. Operating since the early 20th century, Batts Combe is owned and operated byHanson plcHanson Aggregates. The output in 2005 was around 4,000 tonnes of limestone per day, one third of which was supplied to an on-site lime kiln, which closed in 2009;cite newsCheddar Valley Gazette26 March 2009http://www.thisissomerset.co.uk/cheddarvalley/news/Jobs-kiln-closed/article-843237-detail/article.htmlJobs may go as kiln is closed29 March 2009the remainder was sold as coated or dusted aggregates. The limestone at this site is close to 99 percentcarbonateofcalciumandmagnesium(dolomite).Cite bookAtthillRobinhttp://books.google.com/?idMendip: A new study197622David & CharlesNewton Abbott0-7153-7297-1

The Chelmscombe Quarry finished its work as a limestone quarry in the 1950s and was then used by theCentral Electricity Generating Boardas atower testing station.cite webWest Mendip Quarrieshttp://www.bgs.ac.uk/mendips/more_info/west_mendip_quarries_history.htmBritish Geological Survey22 February 2011During the 1970s and 1980s it was also used to test the ability of containers of radioactive material to withstand impacts and other accidents.cite journalDropping a nuclear brickNew ScientistOctober 197360868185http://books.google.co.uk/books?id22 February 2011InformationReed Business
article.heading: Climate
article.paragraph: Along with the rest ofSouth West England, Cheddar has a temperate climate which is generally wetter and milder than the rest of the country.cite webSouth West England: climateMet Officehttp://www.metoffice.gov.uk/climate/uk/sw/14 March 2010The annual mean temperature is approximatelyconvert10°C°F1.TemperatenessSeasonal temperature variationis less extreme than most of the United Kingdom because of the adjacent sea, which moderates temperature. The summer months of July and August are the warmest with mean daily maxima of approximatelyconvert21°C°F1. In winter mean minimum temperatures ofconvert1°C°F1orconvert2°C°F1are common.In the summer theAzoreshigh-pressure system affects the south-west of England.Convectivecloud sometimes forms inland, reducing the number of hours of sunshine; annual sunshine rates are slightly less than the regional average of 1,600 hours.In December 1998 there were 20 days without sun recorded at Yeovilton. Most the rainfall in the south-west is caused byLow-pressure areaAtlantic depressionsor byconvection. Most of the rainfall in autumn and winter is caused by the Atlantic depressions, which are most active during those seasons. In summer, a large proportion of the rainfall is caused by sun heating the ground leading to convection and to showers and thunderstorms. Average rainfall is aroundconvert700mmon. About 815 days of snowfall per year is typical. November to March have the highest mean wind speeds, and June to August have the lightest winds. The predominant wind direction is from the south-west.

article.paragraph: The parish has a population of 5,093,with a mean age of 43 years.cite webhttp://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?aArea: Cheddar CP (Parish)Parish Profile—People ONS Neighbourhood StatisticsOffice for National Statistics30 March 2010Residents live in 2,209 households. The vast majority of households (2,183) give their ethnic status as white.cite webhttp://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?aArea: Cheddar CP (Parish) Parish Profile—Households2001 Census Neighbourhood StatisticsOffice for National Statistics30 March 2010
article.heading: Economy
article.paragraph: File:Cheddar Youth Hostel - geograph.org.uk - 11648.jpgthumbleftCheddar Youth HostelThe village gave its name toCheddar cheese,cite newsSeparating the curds from the wheyhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/5241544.stm[[BBC Radio 4]] Open Country21 August 2006SmaleWill7 August 2007which is the most popular type of cheese in the United Kingdom.cite webThe Interview—Lactalis McLelland's 'Seriously': driving the Cheddar marketThe Grocery Traderhttp://www.grocerytrader.co.uk/News/October_2006/G_lactalis.html9 May 2007The cheese is now made and consumed worldwide, and only one producer remains in the village.

Since the 1880s, Cheddar's other main produce has been theGarden strawberrystrawberry,Cite bookRendellJ.1973Economic problems of the protected strawberry crop in south west EnglandActa HorticulturaeInternational Society for Horticultural Sciencehttp://www.actahort.org/books/30/30_26.htm6 February 2011which is grown on the south-facing lower slopes of the Mendip hills.As a consequence of its use for transporting strawberries to market, the since-closedCheddar Valley linebecame known asThe Strawberry Lineafter it opened in 1869.cite webhttp://www.sustrans.org.uk/assets/files/leaflets/Strawberry%20Line%20leaflet.pdfPDFSustransThe Strawberry Line25 April 2010cite webhttp://www.thestrawberryline.co.uk/d/103/Search_Results.php?docArchiveThe Strawberry Line25 April 2010The line ran fromYattontoWells, SomersetWells. When the rest of the line was closed and all passenger services ceased, the section of the line between Cheddar and Yatton remained open for goods traffic. It provided a fast link with the main markets for the strawberries inBirminghamand London, but finally closed in 1964,Daniels-NoMore3rd16becoming part of the Cheddar Valley Railway Nature Reserve.cite webhttp://www.forestofavon.org/sl.htmlStrawberry Line23 November 2007Forest of Avon

Cheddar Alesis a small brewery based in the village, producing beer for localpublic houses.cite webhttp://www.camrabristol.org.uk/pw72s.pdfPDF7[[Campaign for Real Ale|CAMRA Bristol]]Pints West No. 72 Winter 2006/2007 editionDiscovering Cheddar Ales21 January 2008Tourism is a significant source of employment. Around 15 percent of employment inSedgemooris provided by tourism,cite webhttp://www.sedgemoor.gov.uk/CHttpHandler.ashx?idSedgemoor District Local Plan 1991 – 2011 Adopted VersionRecreation, Leisure and TourismSedgemoor District Council6 June 2012but within Cheddar it is estimated to employ as many as 1,000 people.Cite bookhttp://books.google.com/?idFocus on Geography: Tourism, leisure and recreationGarrettNagleNelson Thornes199954–56978-0-17-444705-4The village also has ayouth hostel,cite webhttp://www.yha.org.uk/find-accommodation/south-west-england/hostels/cheddar/index.aspx[[Youth Hostels Association (England & Wales)|YHA]]Cheddar Youth Hostel30 March 2010and a number of camping and caravan sites.cite webhttp://www.cheddarvillage.org.uk/accommodation/camping-and-caravanning/Campsites and caravan sitesCheddar Web Site6 June 2012

article.heading: Landmarks
article.paragraph: File:Cheddar Cross.jpgthumbPhotochromof Cheddar Market Cross in the 1890sTheMarket Cross, Cheddarmarket crossin Bath Street dates from the 15th century, with the shelter having been rebuilt in 1834. It has a central octagonal pier, a socket raised on four steps, a hexagonal shelter with six arched four-centred openings, shallow two-stage buttresses at each angle, and an embattled parapet. The shaft is crowned by anabacuswith figures in niches, probably from the late 19th century, although the cross is now missing. It was rebuilt byThomas Thynne, 1st Marquess of BathThomas, Marquis of Bath. It is aScheduled Ancient Monument(Somerset County No 21) and Grade II*listed building.cite webMarket Cross[[Images of England]][[English Heritage]]http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id9 May 2006In January 2000, the cross was seriously damaged in a traffic accident.Cite newsMarket cross was reduced to rubble in costly smashIanMatCheddar Valley Gazette28 January 2010cite newshttp://www.thisissomerset.co.uk/news/Putting-names-Market-Cross-faces/article-1809464-detail/article.htmlPutting names to Market Cross facesCheddar Valley Gazette5 February 201030 March 2010By 2002, the cross had been rebuilt and the area around it was redesigned to protect and enhance its appearance.cite webhttp://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/hes/downloads/AnnualReport02.pdfSomerset HeritagePDFAnnual Report 20021330 March 2010The cross was badly damaged again in March 2012, when a taxi crashed into it late at night demolishing two sides.cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-17572356[[BBC News]]Cheddar's medieval cross damaged in taxi crash31 March 2012cite newshttp://www.itv.com/news/west/story/2012-03-31/taxi-crashes-into-cheddars-market-cross/[[ITV News]]Taxi Crashes into Cheddar's Market Cross31 March 2012Repair work, which included the addition of wooden-clad steel posts to protect against future crashes, was completed in November 2012 at a cost of 60,000.cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-20250354BBC News7 November 20128 November 2012Cheddar's medieval cross repaired after taxi crash

Hannah More, a philanthropist and educator, founded a school in the village in the late 18th century for the children of miners. Her first school was located in a 17th-century house. Now named "Hannah More's Cottage",cite webhttp://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id[[Images of England]][[English Heritage]]Hannah More's Cottage31 March 2008the Grade II-listed building is used by the local community as a meeting place.cite webHannah Mores Cottage, Cheddarhttp://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-268787-hannah-mores-cottage-cheddarBritish Listed BuildingsHistory in Structure5 March 2011

It was on theCheddar Valley line, a railway line that was opened in 1869 and closed in 1963. It became known as The Strawberry Line because of the large volume of locally-grownstrawberriesthat it carried. It ran fromYatton railway stationthroughstnlnkCheddartoWells (Tucker Street) railway stationand joined theEast Somerset Railwayto make a through route viaShepton Mallet (High Street) railway stationtoWitham (Somerset) railway stationWitham. Sections of the now-disused railway have been opened as the Strawberry Line Trail, which currently runs from Yatton to Cheddar. The Cheddar Valley line survived until the "Beeching Axe". Towards the end of its life there were so few passengers that dieselrailcarswere sometimes used. The Cheddar branch closed to passengers on 9 September 1963 and to goods in 1964.The line closed in the 1960s, when it became part of the Cheddar Valley Railway Nature Reserve,and part of theNational Cycle Networkroute 26. The cycle route also intersects with the WestMendip Wayand various other footpaths.cite webhttp://www.movingsomersetforward.co.uk/files/uploads/maps/CheddarWEB.pdfCycling Map 10 Cheddar and AxbridgeMoving Somerset ForwardPDF30 March 2010

article.paragraph: File:S3010334-cropped.jpgthumbleftThe Kings of Wessex Academyseen from the tower of St. Andrew's Church (looking north-west)Cheddar has three schools belonging to the Cheddar Valley Group of Schools, twelve schools that provide Cheddar Valley'sthree-tier educationsystem.cite webhttp://www.markfirstschool.ik.org/documents/1086325389.ikml#sbt8Mark First SchoolProspectus5 February 2011Cheddar First School has ten classes for children between 4 and 9 years.cite webhttp://www.cheddarfirst.ik.org/Cheddar First SchoolCheddar First School30 March 2010Fairlands Middle School, amiddle schoolcategorised as a middle-deemed-secondary school, has 510 pupils between 9 and 13.cite webhttps://slp2.somerset.gov.uk/schools/fms/Site%20Pages/About%20the%20School.aspxSchool ProfileFairlands Middle School5 February 2011Fairlands takes children moving up from Cheddar First School as well as other first schools in the Cheddar Valley.The Kings of Wessex Academy, a coeducationalcomprehensive school, has been rated as "outstanding" byOfsted.cite webhttp://www.ofsted.gov.uk/oxedu_reports/display/(id)/117057The Kings of Wessex School Inspection report[[Ofsted]]1 March 20102 March 2010It has 1,182 students aged 13 to 18,cite webhttp://www.ofsted.gov.uk/oxedu_providers/full/(urn)/123896The Kings of Wessex School[[Ofsted]]27 March 2010including 302 in thesixth form. Kings is afaith schoollinked to theChurch of England. It was awarded theSpecialist schoolspecialist statusofTechnology Collegein 2001, enabling it to develop its Information Technology (IT) facilities and improve courses in science, mathematics and design technology. In 2007 it became afoundation school, giving it more control over its own finances. The academy owns and runs a sports centre and swimming pool, Kings Fitness & Leisure, with facilities that are used by students as well as residents. Community education project I.T. for the Terrified, which was originally set up in Wedmore in 1999,cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2886013.stmBBC News25 March 2003Village's cyber cafe opens 27 January 2011is based in an old cow shed on the school's grounds.cite journalhttp://www.kowessex.co.uk/downloads/newsletters/kings_messenger_86.pdfPDFKings MessengerIssue 86[[The Kings of Wessex School]]July 200927 January 2010

article.paragraph: File:Cheddarchurch.jpgthumbChurch of St Andrew, CheddarChurch of St AndrewTheChurch of St Andrew, CheddarChurch of St Andrewdates from the 14th century.
